facts.text: Six appeals by special leave filed against judgment and orders dated July 28, 1954, of the U. P. Board of Revenue in Second Appeals Nos. 430-435 of 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated July 28, 1954, of the U. P. Board of Revenue in Second Appeals Nos. 430-435 of 1953-54, arising out of the judgment and orders dated April 28, 1954, of the Court of the Additional Commissioner, Meerut Division, Meerut, in Appeals Nos. 455-460 of 1954 against the judgment and orders dated March 16, 1954, of the Addl. District Magistrate, Meerut, in Cases Nos. 389-394 of 1950.

facts.text: Respondent was a Zamindar of Gadhi, Baghu and Santokpore Villages in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a Zamindar of Gadhi, Baghu and Santokpore Villages in Uttar Pradesh. He claimed that the plaint- schedule lands were his Sir.

facts.text: Respondent claimed that the plaint-schedule lands were his Sir.

anchor.surface_text: He claimed that the plaint- schedule lands were his Sir. The appellants set up a dispute claiming that they were admitted by the respondent as hereditary tenants and that they were in possession of the said lands.

facts.text: Appellants claimed they were admitted by the respondent as hereditary tenants and were in possession of the said lands.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants set up a dispute claiming that they were admitted by the respondent as hereditary tenants and that they were in possession of the said lands. As the dispute was likely to cause breach of the peace, the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Baghpat, took proceedings under s. 145, Code of Criminal Procedure, and attached the disputed lands on October 8, 1948,

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Baghpat, took proceedings under s. 145 CrPC and attached disputed lands on October 8, 1948, placed in possession of a supurdgiar pending disposal.

anchor.surface_text: As the dispute was likely to cause breach of the peace, the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Baghpat, took proceedings under s. 145, Code of Criminal Procedure, and attached the disputed lands on October 8, 1948, and directed them to be placed in possession of a superdgidar pending disposal of those proceedings.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate by order dated March 20, 1950, found appellants in possession and declared them entitled until evicted in due course of law.

anchor.surface_text: After making the necessary enquiry, by an order dated March 20, 1950, he found that the appellants were in possession of the said lands and declared that they were entitled to be in possession thereof until evicted therefrom in due companyrse of law.

facts.text: On June 30, 1950, respondent filed six suits in Revenue Court Additional Collector, Meerut against appellants under s. 180 U.P. Tenancy Act for eviction and damages.

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, 1950, the respondent filed six suits in the Revenue Court  Additional Collector, Meerut  against the appellants under s. 180 of the U. P. Tenancy Act  U. P. 17 of 1939 , hereinafter called the Act, for evicting them from -the said lands and for damages.

facts.text: Respondent alleged in suits that disputed lands were his Sir lands and appellants trespassed based on wrong order of Criminal Court.

anchor.surface_text: He alleged therein that the disputed lands were his Sir lands and that the appellants trespassed on the same on the basis of a wrong order of the Criminal Court.

facts.text: Appellants pleaded they were admitted as hereditary tenants by respondent after receiving Rs. 40,000 premium.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants pleaded, inter alia, that they had been admitted as hereditary tenants by the respondent after receiving from them a sum of Rs. 40,000 towards premium.

facts.text: Suits consolidated but stayed on August 14, 1951, under r. 4 of Rules under U.P. Ordinance No. III of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The suits were companysolidated, but were stayed on August 14, 1951, under r. 4 of the Rules made under the U. P. Ordinance No. III of 1951.

facts.text: On September 22, 1952, Revenue Court ordered restarting trial of suits on respondent's application under r.5.

anchor.surface_text: On September 22, 1952, on an application made by the respondent, the Revenue Court ordered under r. 5 for restarting the trial of the suits.

facts.text: Revenue Court transferred suits to Civil Court for retrial, but first Additional Munsif, Ghaziabad retransferred to Revenue Court.

anchor.surface_text: After the said order, the Revenue Court transferred the suits to the Civil Court for retrial, but the first Additional Munsif, Ghaziabad, to whom the suits were transferred, held that the said suits were triable only by the Revenue Court and retransferred the same to that Court.

facts.text: Additional Collector, Meerut held lands were Sir and Khud kasht of respondent and appellants not admitted as hereditary tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Collector, Meerut, held, on evidence, that the said lands were Sir and Khud kasht of the respondent and that the appellants were number admitted thereto as hereditary tenants.

facts.text: Appellants preferred six appeals to Court of Commissioner at Meerut against decrees of Additional Collector.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants preferred six appeals against the decrees of the Additional Collector in the six suits to the Court of the Commissioner at Meerut.

facts.text: Additional Commissioner held appeal by legal representatives of Jahana abated due to no vakalat filed.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Commissioner, who heard the appeals, held that one of the appeals filed by the legal representatives of Jahana, the plaintiff in the suit which gave rise to that appeal, had number been properly presented on the ground that Shri Brahmanand Sharma, Vakil, did number file in the suit any vakalat given to him by the legal representatives of the deceased and therefore the appeal had abated,

facts.text: Additional Commissioner held since suits consolidated, decision in one suit res judicata in others.

anchor.surface_text: and that as all the suits were companysolidated with the companysent of the parties, the decision in the suit became final and operated as res judicata in the other appeals.

facts.text: Additional Commissioner agreed lands in dispute were Sir and appellants not hereditary tenants.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, he agreed with the trial Court in holding that the lands in dispute were Sir and that the appellants were number hereditary tenants.

facts.text: Appellants filed six second appeals to Board of Revenue at Allahabad against Additional Commissioner's order.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellants preferred six second appeals against the said order of the Additional Commissioner to the Board of Revenue at Allahabad.

facts.text: Board of Revenue accepted findings of lower courts and dismissed appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Revenue accepted the findings of the two Courts, and also it negatived the plea raised by the appellants for the first time to the effect that the suits were number maintainable in the Revenue Court. In the result, the appeals were dismissed.

facts.text: Three courts concurrently held appellants were not hereditary tenants of disputed lands.

anchor.surface_text: The three Courts have companycurrently held on a companysideration of oral and documentary evidence that they were number hereditary tenants.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts concurrent finding that appellants not hereditary tenants as one of fact not vitiated by error of law.

anchor.surface_text: The companycurrent finding of the three Courts to the effect that the appellants are number hereditary tenants is essentially one of fact and is number vitiated by any error of law. Following the usual practice of this Court, we must accept the finding.

facts.text: Additional Collector awarded damages based on annual rent though no witness deposed and no argument advanced.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Collector gave damages though neither the witnesses deposed to it number the Advocate advanced any argument thereon.

facts.text: Suits stayed on August 14, 1951 due to U.P. Government Notification dated August 9, 1951 under Ordinance No. III of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: To appreciate this companytention some relevant facts may be -recapitulated. On August 14, 1951, the six suits were stayed in view of the U. P. Government Notification dated August 9, 1951, issued under Ordinance No. III of 1951.

facts.text: Additional Collector, Meerut ordered restarting of suits on September 22, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: an order directing the restarting of the suits was made by the Additional Collector, Meerut, on September 22,  1   1901  L.R. 29 I.A. 24, 33. 1952.

facts.text: Rules amended on October 8, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It, may also be mentioned that the rules were amended on October 8, 1952, i. e., after the order directing the restarting of the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Section 79 of the Evidence Act reads The Court shall presume to be genuine every document purporting to be a certificate which is by law declared to be admissible as evidence of any particular fact, and which purports to be duly certified by any officer -of the Central Government or of a State Government Provided that such document is substantially in the form and purports to be executed in the manner directed by law in that behalf.

concepts.interpretation: Court must presume certified copy genuine if substantially in form and manner provided by law; rebuttable presumption.

arguments.claim: Board of Revenue rejected abatement contention as suits within exception to r.5

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the Board of Revenue that the suits had abated under cl. v of r. 4 of the Rules, but the Board of Revenue rejected their contention on the ground that the suits fell within the exception to r. 5.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ide a partys title or right to possession of the land but expressly reserves that question to be decided in due companyrse of law. The foundation of h

holdings.text: The concurrent finding of the three Courts to the effect that the appellants are not hereditary tenants is essentially one of fact and is not vitiated by any error of law. Following the usual practice of this Court, we must accept the finding.

anchor.surface_text: The concurrent finding of the three Courts to the effect that the appellants are not hereditary tenants is essentially one of fact and is not vitiated by any error of law. Following the usual practice of this Court, we must accept the finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's alleged errors of law (presumption under Evidence Act, burden from s.145, ignored evidence, different standards, ss.10/16/20) rejected; concurrent fact finding binding absent legal error.

holdings.text: The Courts were not bound to draw the presumption under Section 79 of the Evidence Act in respect of the certified copy of the khatauni as it was not substantially in the form and manner directed by law.

anchor.surface_text: Section 79 of the Evidence Act reads The Court shall presume to be genuine every document purporting to be a certificate which is by law declared to be admissible as evidence of any particular fact, and which purports to be duly certified by any officer -of the Central Government or of a State Government Provided that such document is substantially in the form and purports to be executed in the manner directed by law in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certified copy lacked diary entry and fee per U.P. Land Records Manual; presumption rebuttable and rebutted by internal/external evidence.

holdings.text: The order under s.145 CrPC does not throw the burden of proof on the respondent; immaterial as findings based on entire evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there any merit in the second point either. The order of the Magistrate under s. 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure may, at best, throw the burden of proof on the plaintiff but in the present case the question of burden of proof is not material, for the findings of the three Courts were arrived at on a consideration of the entire evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.145 order provisional; courts considered all evidence.

holdings.text: Courts did not ignore material evidence or apply different standards of proof.

anchor.surface_text: Though the learned Counsel says that material evidence has been ignored by the Courts, he has not been able to point out what evidence has been excluded. The Courts have considered the entire evidence placed before them and the findings were based on an appreciation of the said evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No specific evidence identified as ignored; each document assessed independently.

holdings.text: Sections 10, 16 and 20 of the U.P. Tenancy Act presuppose tenancy and are inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 10, 16 and 20 of the U. P. Tenancy Act presuppose that the person claiming rights thereunder is a tenant, and, on the finding that the appellants are not tenants, there is no scope for invoking the said provisions.

holdings.text: The finding on damages is not open to challenge as not raised in lower appeals or statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: The correctness of this finding was not canvassed either in the first appellate Court or in the second appellate Court nor does the statement of case filed in this Court disclose any grievance on that score.

holdings.text: Suits under s.180 U.P. Tenancy Act are maintainable in Revenue Court against person occupying land without title; possession under s.145 CrPC is not 'in accordance with the provisions of the law for the time being in force'.

anchor.surface_text: We may now advert to the main and substantial contention of the appellants, namely that the suits are not maintainable in a Revenue Court. This question turns upon the interpretation of s. 180 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.180 for ejectment without consent or lawful possession; s.145 temporary police measure decides no title (Dinomoni PC); heading/Sch.4 confirm 'without title'; distinguishes tenant ejectment ss.155-179.

holdings.text: A provisional order of a Magistrate under s.145 CrPC irrespective of rights cannot enable resistance to suit under s.180.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that a provisional order of a Magistrate in regard to possession irrespective of the rights of the parties cannot enable a person to resist the suit under s. 180 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.145 declares possession on date only, no title/right; temporary until civil eviction.

holdings.text: Suits did not abate under r.5 of amended Rules as restarted under original r.5 before amendment; no subsisting stay; exception applies to Sir lands where no rights accrued to defendants.

anchor.surface_text: To appreciate this contention some relevant facts may be -recapitulated. On August 14, 1951, the six suits were stayed in view of the U. P. Government Notification dated August 9, 1951, issued under Ordinance No. III of 1951.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restart on 22.9.1952 under original rules; amendment 8.10.1952; r.4 exception for Sir/no rights under s.16 ZALR; r.5 conditioned on r.4 stay.

holdings.text: r.5 of the amended Rules cannot be invoked in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: On the said facts, the first question is whether r. 5 of the amended Rules would apply to a case which was restarted under the provisions of the original Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No stay under amended r.4 after restart; exception applies.

precedents.cited_holding: These orders are merely police orders made to prevent breaches of the peace. They decide numberquestion of title

The correctness of this finding was not canvassed either in the first appellate Court or in the second appellate Court nor does the statement of case filed in this Court disclose any grievance on that score.

As we are rejecting the contentions of the learned Counsel for the appellants on all the other points, the correctness of the decision of the Revenue Board on the said two points would number affect the result of the appeals.
